title: Victim Was Gunman’s Co-Worker
content:
Nicholas Thalasinos, a 52-year-old health department co-worker of Syed Rizwan Farook's, was among the 14 people killed in the shooting, his wife said on Thursday. 

In a phone interview, Jennifer Thalasinos said that her husband of nine years had been friendly with Mr. Farook, and that they were part of the same "little group" of employees. According to records, Mr. Thalasinos  worked as an environmental health specialist in San Bernardino, as did  Mr. Farook. 

"He had worked with him," Ms. Thalasinos said of her husband.  "He had talked about him. Nothing negative." 

Ms. Thalasinos said she and her husband were devout Messianic Jews, members of a religious group that incorporates elements of Judaism and Christianity. She said  Mr. Thalasinos had worn  traditional Jewish tassels, called tzitzit, on his pants. 

On Facebook, Mr. Thalasinos appeared to hold politically conservative views, and he posted often about his faith. 

Ms. Thalasinos said  her husband would have had "no clue" if Mr. Farook had been radicalized. 

"My husband was very outspoken about ISIS and all of these radicalized Muslims," she said, adding, "If he would’ve thought that somebody in his office was like that, he would’ve said something."
content_expanded:
Nicholas Thalasinos, a 52-year-old health department co-worker of Syed Rizwan Farook’s, was among the 14 people killed in the shooting, his wife said on Thursday.

In a phone interview, Jennifer Thalasinos said that her husband of nine years had been friendly with Mr. Farook, and that they were part of the same “little group” of employees. According to records, Mr. Thalasinos worked as an environmental health specialist in San Bernardino, as did Mr. Farook.

“He had worked with him,” Ms. Thalasinos said of her husband. “He had talked about him. Nothing negative.”

Ms. Thalasinos said she and her husband were devout Messianic Jews, members of a religious group that incorporates elements of Judaism and Christianity. She said Mr. Thalasinos had worn traditional Jewish tassels, called tzitzit, on his pants.

On Facebook, Mr. Thalasinos appeared to hold politically conservative views, and he posted often about his faith.

Ms. Thalasinos said her husband would have had “no clue” if Mr. Farook had been radicalized.

“My husband was very outspoken about ISIS and all of these radicalized Muslims,” she said, adding, “If he would’ve thought that somebody in his office was like that, he would’ve said something.”

title: Investigators Warn Against Terrorism Conclusion
content:
Two senior United States security officials said that F.B.I. counter-terrorism officials are overseeing the investigation because of the possibility that it might be terrorism, not because they had concluded that it was.
 
The two officials called the case perplexing, saying that no clear evidence of terrorism had emerged, and that there were some signs pointing away from it. But they said the shooting was clearly premeditated, and does not fit the mold for typical workplace violence incidents. The idea that this was a workplace argument that spiraled out of control seems far-fetched now, the officials said, given the explosives and the preparation.

An overnight review of Mr. Farook's electronic devices hasn't provided clear answers to these questions, but the officials noted that the investigation is in its early phases. 

David Bowdich, the assistant director for the F.B.I.'s Los Angeles office, summarized the view of investigators at this point in the process. 
 
"It'd be irresponsible and premature of me to call it terrorism," he said.
content_expanded:
Two senior United States security officials said that F.B.I. counter-terrorism officials are overseeing the investigation because of the possibility that it might be terrorism, not because they had concluded that it was.

The two officials called the case perplexing, saying that no clear evidence of terrorism had emerged, and that there were some signs pointing away from it. But they said the shooting was clearly premeditated, and does not fit the mold for typical workplace violence incidents. The idea that this was a workplace argument that spiraled out of control seems far-fetched now, the officials said, given the explosives and the preparation.

An overnight review of Mr. Farook’s electronic devices hasn’t provided clear answers to these questions, but the officials noted that the investigation is in its early phases.

David Bowdich, the assistant director for the F.B.I.’s Los Angeles office, summarized the view of investigators at this point in the process.

“It’d be irresponsible and premature of me to call it terrorism,” he said.

title: County Offices Closed
content:
Offices of the San Bernardino Department of Public Health were dark on Thursday. A sign on the door announced that all county offices would be  closed Through Dec. 7.

The shooting rampage Wednesday took place at an annual holiday party for the department, where one of the shooting suspects, Syed Rizwan Farook, worked for five years as an environmental inspector, officials said.
content_expanded:
Offices of the San Bernardino Department of Public Health were dark on Thursday. A sign on the door announced that all county offices would be closed Through Dec. 7.

The shooting rampage Wednesday took place at an annual holiday party for the department, where one of the shooting suspects, Syed Rizwan Farook, worked for five years as an environmental inspector, officials said.

title: Motive Still Unknown
content:
We do not yet know the motive... There was obviously a mission here. We do not know why.
-- David Bowdich, assistant director in charge of the F.B.I.'s Los Angeles office
content_expanded:
We do not yet know the motive… There was obviously a mission here. We do not know why.

— David Bowdich, assistant director in charge of the F.B.I.’s Los Angeles office

title: Police: 21 Wounded, 12 Pipe Bombs Discovered
content:
San Bernardino Police Chief Jarrod Burguan said there were 21 people injured in the attack, updating the previous tally of 17. And he said that investigators found 12 pipe bombs at the home of the suspects, searched after the killings. 

He said the police believe the suspects fired 65-75 rounds when they entered. There were also pipe bombs with remote controlled bombs and four high capacity .223 caliber magazines of ammunition left as evidence.

The suspects were wearing black tactical gear but not bullet proof vests.

Chief Burguan said that in the shootout with the suspects, law enforcement fired 380 rounds at suspects, and the suspects fired 76 rounds at the officers. In their vehicle, a black Ford Expedition that Mr. Farook rented a few days ago, Chief Burgan said, officers found more than 1,400 .223-caliber rounds and 200 9-mm rounds with the suspects or immediately in the vehicle. 

Two officers were injured. Initial reporters counted only one officer injured. 

"We don't know if they were planning another attack," Chief Burguan said, adding that the police have no information any further  immediate threat to anyone in the region.

He said that the suspect, Mr. Farook, was in the room during the early part of the event, a holiday party for county public health department where he worked but that investigators were not aware of any grudge against his co-workers.

"We still don't have the motive," Chief Burguan said, adding that because "they sprayed the room with bullets," it was not clear if anyone in particular was targeted.
content_expanded:
San Bernardino Police Chief Jarrod Burguan said there were 21 people injured in the attack, updating the previous tally of 17. And he said that investigators found 12 pipe bombs at the home of the suspects, searched after the killings.

He said the police believe the suspects fired 65-75 rounds when they entered. There were also pipe bombs with remote controlled bombs and four high capacity .223 caliber magazines of ammunition left as evidence.

The suspects were wearing black tactical gear but not bullet proof vests.

Chief Burguan said that in the shootout with the suspects, law enforcement fired 380 rounds at suspects, and the suspects fired 76 rounds at the officers. In their vehicle, a black Ford Expedition that Mr. Farook rented a few days ago, Chief Burgan said, officers found more than 1,400 .223-caliber rounds and 200 9-mm rounds with the suspects or immediately in the vehicle.

Two officers were injured. Initial reporters counted only one officer injured.

“We don’t know if they were planning another attack,” Chief Burguan said, adding that the police have no information any further immediate threat to anyone in the region.

He said that the suspect, Mr. Farook, was in the room during the early part of the event, a holiday party for county public health department where he worked but that investigators were not aware of any grudge against his co-workers.

“We still don’t have the motive,” Chief Burguan said, adding that because “they sprayed the room with bullets,” it was not clear if anyone in particular was targeted.

title: Law Enforcement Treating Attack as Counterterrorism Investigaton
content:
The F.B.I. is treating its investigation into the San Bernardino massacre as a counterterrorism investigation, two law enforcement officials said Thursday. 

That decision is based in part on the nature of the attack, in which the suspects — Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik — arrived at the Inland Regional Center in tactical gear, with four weapons and explosive devices. They also cited what they described as Mr. Farook's links to suspected Muslim extremists both domestically and abroad.

But the officials said they were unclear what set off the attack, given that it was against his co-workers. They said it might have involved grievances against them.  

"You don't take your wife to a workplace shooting, and especially not as prepared as they were," said a senior law enforcement official briefed on the investigation. "He could have been radicalized, ready to go with some kind of attack, and then had a dispute at work, and decided to do something."

The F.B.I. has also uncovered evidence that Mr. Farook had been in touch with people domestically and abroad who have extremist views, according to law enforcement officials. Mr. Farook had contact with them over several years, the officials said.
 At least one of those individuals in the United States was investigated for terrorism by federal authorities in recent years, although that case did not result in charges, the officials said.
content_expanded:
The F.B.I. is treating its investigation into the San Bernardino massacre as a counterterrorism investigation, two law enforcement officials said Thursday.

That decision is based in part on the nature of the attack, in which the suspects — Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik — arrived at the Inland Regional Center in tactical gear, with four weapons and explosive devices. They also cited what they described as Mr. Farook’s links to suspected Muslim extremists both domestically and abroad.

But the officials said they were unclear what set off the attack, given that it was against his co-workers. They said it might have involved grievances against them.

“You don’t take your wife to a workplace shooting, and especially not as prepared as they were,” said a senior law enforcement official briefed on the investigation. “He could have been radicalized, ready to go with some kind of attack, and then had a dispute at work, and decided to do something.”

The F.B.I. has also uncovered evidence that Mr. Farook had been in touch with people domestically and abroad who have extremist views, according to law enforcement officials. Mr. Farook had contact with them over several years, the officials said.
At least one of those individuals in the United States was investigated for terrorism by federal authorities in recent years, although that case did not result in charges, the officials said.

title: Official Says Suspect Went on Hajj
content:
Three congressional officials  briefed on the investigation  said  the authorities believe that one of the suspects, Syed Rizwan Farook,  traveled to Saudi Arabia for a pilgrimage, or hajj,  to Mecca.

"He went to the hajj," in 2013, one of the officials said, and made "multiple trips" to Saudi Arabia.

"They don't think it was for nefarious activity, but more will shake out" after investigators complete an examination of computer and cellphone data, the official said.

According to the official, the female suspect, Tashfeen Malik, entered the United States in 2014 on a K-1 visa, known as a fiancée visa.
content_expanded:
Three congressional officials briefed on the investigation said the authorities believe that one of the suspects, Syed Rizwan Farook, traveled to Saudi Arabia for a pilgrimage, or hajj, to Mecca.

“He went to the hajj,” in 2013, one of the officials said, and made “multiple trips” to Saudi Arabia.

“They don’t think it was for nefarious activity, but more will shake out” after investigators complete an examination of computer and cellphone data, the official said.

According to the official, the female suspect, Tashfeen Malik, entered the United States in 2014 on a K-1 visa, known as a fiancée visa.

title: Investigators Search Door to Door
President Obama Offers Condolences
content:
President Obama said in an Oval Office statement Thursday morning that it was possible  the attacks in San Bernadino  were terrorist-related. But he said it was also possible they were work-related. 

At this stage law enforcement officials still do not know why this “terrible event occurred,” Mr. Obama said. He said he had been briefed on the F.B.I. investigation.

Mr. Obama expressed condolences to the survivors of the 14 victims of the shooting, and said he had spoken with San Bernadino's mayor, R. Carey Davis.

He said many Americans, seeing how prevalent mass shootings are, "feel there is nothing we can do about it."

"We are going to have to search ourselves as a society to take basic steps that would make it harder  — not impossible but harder —  for individuals to get access to weapons," he said.
content_expanded:
President Obama said in an Oval Office statement Thursday morning that it was possible the attacks in San Bernadino were terrorist-related. But he said it was also possible they were work-related.

At this stage law enforcement officials still do not know why this “terrible event occurred,” Mr. Obama said. He said he had been briefed on the F.B.I. investigation.

Mr. Obama expressed condolences to the survivors of the 14 victims of the shooting, and said he had spoken with San Bernadino’s mayor, R. Carey Davis.

He said many Americans, seeing how prevalent mass shootings are, “feel there is nothing we can do about it.”

“We are going to have to search ourselves as a society to take basic steps that would make it harder — not impossible but harder — for individuals to get access to weapons,” he said.

title: Establishing a Perimeter
